data.text: Road or Hybrid Bike for Long Distance?
Which type of bicycle would be more practical for this type of riding? Road bike or hybrid bike?
This?
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: I'd pick a gravel bike that has fixing points. Road bikes don't have them and I haven't found a hybrid that rolls as good as even a quality entry level gravel bike.

data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: If you plan in touring mostly on bitumen and good gravel with traditional panniers - a touring bike (I have a Surly Long Haul Trucker), if you‚Äôre planning more for gravel and other unpaved trails with a bikepacking set up - a gravel bike. That said any good solid bike can be made serviceable for travel. If you have one that you like, maybe do a first short trip with it and see how you go.
data.author: Elizabeth Cage

data.text: Touring Bike.Gravel or even MTB. No Road bike.no hybrid. I would go for a steel frame.
data.author: Marion Langer

data.text: Also when going of paved roads and whenever with heavy loads i would go with wheels 27.5 or even smaller. On pure paved roadtrips any touring bike with big wheels 28... but the gravel bike i would only consider when going for shorter trips any terrain with less equipment... Not laoding it to heavely..
data.author: Marion Langer

data.text: I have a specialized hybrid and prefer it to a road bike because the tires don't wear down as fast and its more capable in the grass.

data.text: For what type of riding? Black top, gravel, some off road? Day riders, overnighters, longer tours? Will you be carrying a load and if so, ultralight (frame bags, handlebar roll) or fully loaded (2 panniers or 4?)?

data.author: Steven Mullis

data.text: If that's your only choice, I'd say that a hybrid is better and more versatile than a road bike... But nothing beats a proper touring bike made out of steel.
data.author: Gian Carlo Rivera

data.text: Any bike with dual suspension and a lot of mounting points! I have done 10574km but the electric assistance helped a lot uphills!‚úåÔ∏è Should you not have unlimited time then definitely ho electric. Otherwise it won't matter if you ride 20km a day to 60km a day. I have mostly done 294km a day with an average of 150km a day
data.author: Lauren»õiu Macovei

data.text: dual suspension would be a last choice for touring. Then you have the weight of the suspension, as well as no room for a frame bag or second bottle holder. As well as everytime it's time to climb a mountain it'll be time to lock the rear suspension unless you like bouncing up and down while pedaling. I've had a lot of bikes, still have one with dual suspension. I wouldn't recomend that for touring though, I wouldn't even recomend front. It makes it harder to find racks and support as much. It can be done but better without. I'm just setting this one up now, I would have preferred no front suspension but the price was right.
data.author: Joe Fowler

data.text: have you tried or thought of full suspension with a trailer?
data.author: Ian Chilver

data.text: yes. How do you figure that helps? I had to look back at long way to find this. As like most people I quit towing with a full suspension bike years ago. It was stupid to try but it was my only bike then. Have you really not noticed everybody else has said no suspension? Of course most guys under 60 under using a battery.
data.author: Joe Fowler

data.text: yes I noticed but that was in respect of panniers rather than trailers. To be fair I don‚Äôt like your attitude and if you feel the need to be a dick then it‚Äôs probably best just not to say anything.
data.author: Ian Chilver

data.text: don't give shit advice than. That's being a dick. Reasons it's shit advice. 1 Need to lock out the suspension to avoid wasting all your energy on hills. 2. Adds weight to the total and its completely unnecessary as it's usually locked out. 3. As you mentioned panniers. Hard to haul anything if you can only use those 20 pound racks that hang off the seatpost, and what else is there unless you lock the rear suspension for the entire trip? 4. Suspension is one more thing to service that will eventually have problems. But if you're riding ebikes that doesn't compare to most. I'm only 40 so I've got another 30 years or so until you'll catch me on one of them. If I want to cover ground quick I'll hop on my Harley and cross north America on 3 days. Or I'll use my road bike. Let's face it if you're riding an ebike limited to 32kph after 3 hours of hard riding I'll be about 20kms ahead of you. I'm amazed how much ground I can cover on this. I wouldn't use it for touring though, too short.
data.author: Joe Fowler

data.text: ride comfort is more important than energy with an ebike. You just add an extra battery for all the extra weight and no problems with the range I did max 294km in a day with 5 batteries full suspension, gravel, off-road, grass, dirt, roads, irrelevant All terrain is welcome and max comfort And I had 3 panniers two on sides and one on top of the rack, all 45kg in total and no problems ‚úåÔ∏èüöÄüöÄ
data.author: Lauren»õiu Macovei

data.text: if it works for you do it. For the last 15 years or so I've road nothing but full suspension. Earlier this year I tried a friend's Jamis Durango and liked it so much I bought it off hi. Since then I've bought a few road bikes, and a couple more mountain bikes and I honestly don't think I'll ever buy a bicycle with rear suspension again. For touring I'm even hesitant about front suspension. But I'll be riding one with a hybrid with front shocks next your touring as it was just too good a deal to pass on. It was on clearout so the almost twin bike but with no front suspension would have cost more then double.
data.author: Joe Fowler

data.text: Here's my GT Transeo 3.0 hybrid bike, they call it City Cross (based on the sticker in the frame).

data.text: Any bike, just as long as its comfortable and strong
data.author: Mountcraig King

data.text: Something in steel. It‚Äôs a more comfortable ride. Steel frames also have multiple mounting points for cargo racks that carry panniers. ÔøºÔøº Handlebars that offer different grip positions are very desirable. Ôøº
data.author: Louie Garcia

data.text: You can get started on any bike so long as you can carry a bit of luggage. Don't spend lots of money until you have tried a few things and know what you want to do. Start with short trips and learn as you go along.
data.author: Simon Lambourn

data.text: Hybrid steel frame from the 90s would be perfect. I'm thinking specialized crossroads if you want 2.0 size tires
data.author: Bogdan C. Cojocaru

data.text: That paired with some schwalbe marathon tires
data.author: Bogdan C. Cojocaru

data.text:
A hybrid, if you can't come up with the funds for a touring bike. A little sturdier and more likely to have rack mounts and be built for more abuse. But there's the Long Haul Trucker: https://surlybikes.com/bikes/disc_trucker Or a Trek 520: https://www.trekbikes.com/us/en_US/bikes/bikepacking-touring-bikes/520/520/p/24000/ But I have ridden my Co-Motion through China and all around Europe. It's my favorite bicycle ever and it came from the factory ready to be loaded up and roll, which is rare.
Disc Trucker | Long Distance Touring Bike | Surly Bikes
surlybikes.com
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: It ultimately depends where you are how going and how light you like to travel. If you want to travel very light and stay in guesthouses all the time, no camping, then you can do it on a road bike if most of the roads are bitumen. I know someone who toured in india on a road bike. But not many people do that anymore really.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: Hybrid or gravel. Road bikes tend to be as short as possible and often don't have mounts already. The short part means I end of hitting the back of my shoes on the saddlebags. Also a lot of the newer ones have carbon fiber forks that won't hold a lot and don't have mounts. Gravel or hybrids generally are a bit better. Hybrids are definitely cheaper so that's what I'm setting up now. I just got the front rack and new handlebars on last night. This one has front suspension which I was trying to avoid but it was a clearout deal so I had to try it.
data.author: Joe Fowler

data.text: What is practical for me may be way different from you.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: Neither. If you spend five minutes on here you‚Äôll see most people use touring bikes or gravel bikes.
data.author: Geoffrey Silverstein

data.text: Got this bike Giant Terrago in 2006 fantastic bike use it most days.
data.author: John Kennedy Clark

data.text: What type of riding?
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: Ride what you are comfortable on - but, if you have a chance to try out different bikes that are fully loaded, it may help with your decision. I used a regular road bike on my first trip, and the bike flexed so much under a load that it was hard to ride and the rim brakes were inadequate.
data.author: Banks Upshaw

data.text: Between the two choices, I picked the hybrid. I packed it as a luggage and keep the weight within limit for the airline company. Other gravel and touring bike are also ok. But I have seen people on all kind of bikes. It depends on your budget, location, and length of your trip. Most of my problems were from my cheap paniers. I have to improvise all the time to keep them on the bike safely...
data.author: St Chen

data.text: It doesn't matter lol
